Issues.Title: Defer syntax doesn't create lazy chunks when component imported from a barrel
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

compiler

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

When using the new defer syntax with component imported from a barrel file (like a `index.ts` with re-exports) the expected lazy-loaded chunks are not created. Instead, the component is included in the main bundle, which contradicts the intended lazy loading behavior.

### Steps to Reproduce

- Create two components
- Create index.ts file which re-exports them both
- Import both components to the parent using index.ts file
- Add both components to the imports section of parent component
- Use both components in the template
- Wrap one of them to defer block

### Expected behavior

After the build process, the dist directory should contain a lazy-loaded chunk that includes the component wrapper to the defer block.

### Actual Behavior

No lazy-loaded chunks are created. Both components is bundled in the main chunk.

Issues.Title: New docs too clicky - including most important get started
Issues.Body:
### Description of the Issue:

I've encountered navigation and visibility issues on the Angular documentation website, which seem to make the user experience less intuitive, particularly on mobile devices.

### URL of the Affected Page:

[Angular.dev](https://angular.dev)

### Detailed Feedback:

1. **Visibility of Key Information:**
   - The critical command `ng new` is not immediately visible. For comparison, the NX documentation features their equivalent command prominently on the homepage. A direct link to the [guides](https://angular.dev/overview) and [reference](https://angular.dev/api) sections is provided, but the formatting makes it easy to overlook.

2. **General Navigation Concerns:**
   - On mobile, navigating the documentation is cumbersome. After selecting a menu item, the menu closes, and reopening it is necessary to continue to sub-sections, which is not user-friendly.

3. **Documentation Flow:**
   - The "Start Coding" section redirects to a tutorial, which is unexpected. It would be more logical to present `ng new` at this stage.
   - The tutorials page at [First App Tutorial](https://angular.dev/tutorials/first-app) does not mention the `ng new` command. Additionally, it's unclear whether installing Angular globally is still the recommended practice.

4. **Tutorial Navigation:**
   - The dropdown menus in the tutorial section feel clunky. A dual-mode navigation system, allowing users to switch between tutorial steps and direct access to topics, could enhance the experience.

I appreciate the sleek design of the site, but it seems there are opportunities to refine the UX to better support developers. This is a subjective perspective, and I apologize for the brevity of my feedback. I am open to discussing these points further and would be happy to contribute to improving the user experience.

Issues.Title: Supercharge Angular devtools with integration into the Elements tab and allow RxJS to show current values
Issues.Body: ### Is this a bug report or a feature request? - [ ] Bug Report - [X] Feature Request ### Description [Feature Request only] One of the reasons I still prefer [Angular State Inspector](https://chrome.google.com/webstore/detail/angular-state-inspector/nelkodgfpddgpdbcjinaaalphkfffbem) over Angular Devtools is that its inside the Elements tab as a tab next to styles/computed/layout. Being there allows me to easily click the DOM elements and see both their final styles as the properties that are bound to the elements, the state. I would love it if Angular Devtools enabled a similar view that is able to be closer to my code. Another thing that annoys me when inspecting is that RxJS observables, mainly those using async pipes, are difficult to view what they currently hold. Of course I could work around this by logging the item to console and adding functions there to log it, or put break points in my code to see whats what. But I feel thats kinda overkill and not really necessary what helps me quickly view how data flows through my app (especially if you are finding a side-effect of a component that transformed a value that you are looking where it was changed like that). A better integration on RxJS would help junior devs a lot and I think its the main thing missing from devtools. Aside being near what I see when I right click an element to inspect it. Simple state overview on a certain element from angular state inspector: Pretty useless subscription when inspecting an observable in angular devtools: ### Proposed solution [Feature Request only] -Be closer to the regular element inspector, allowing me to quickly see what data these elements hold and what their current value is. -Improve compatibility with RxJS for devtools to not just show operator and source (where operator somehow opens lift.js and source is either an endless list of other operator/source children or it shows _subscribe and when clicking the (...) it just goes to where the observable class was defined) Because what does a dev want to inspect? Actual values, not just the structure of the framework. Because that only answers half the question of "why does it do what it does". ### Alternatives considered [Feature Request only] Of course I can keep using Angular State Inspector but it doesn't seem to be maintained (august 2021 was the last one) while still being a valuable tool for Angular devs.

Issues.Body: When using the `application` or `browser-esbuild` builders, a parallel TS/NG compilation will be used by default via a Node.js Worker. However, when used inside a Web Container, the build will fail to initialize the compilation instance due to what appears to be a defect within Web containers involving the transfer/serialization of a MessageChannel's MessagePort objects. A parallel compilation can still be forced by using the `NG_BUILD_PARALLEL_TS=1` environment variable.

Issues.Title: Importing CSS file from a component's CSS doesn't work
Issues.Body:
### Command

build, serve

### Is this a regression?

- [X] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

16.x.x

### Description

When using the CSS @import statement inside a component's CSS file doesn't include neither the file or the inline style in the bundled result. It did work in Angular 16, even with esbuild.

I've noticed this when trying to create a component with **encapsulation: ViewEncapsulation.ShadowDom**.  As global styles doesn't work in the component, I tried importing those styles (Bootstrap CSS) inside the component's CSS file. This @import statement was not detected and the file contents were not included when executing ng serve or ng build.

In Angular 16, the file contents is included in the components styles property (inline) and works as expected. 

### Minimal Reproduction

Create Angular project (mine is --standalone)
Create a component and put it inside AppComponent: **ng g my-component**
Install Bootstrap: **npm i bootstrap**

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): avoid in-memory prerendering ESM loader errors
Issues.Body:
The in-memory ESM loader hooks have been adjusted to avoid potential errors when
resolving and loading the bundled server code during prerendering. These errors
could result in hard to diagnose build failures. E2E testing via the deprecated
protractor builder, would silently exit, for instance. To ensure on disk files
including node modules are resolved from the workspace root, a virtual file root
is used for all in memory files. This path does not actually exist but is used to
overlay the in memory files with the actual filesystem for resolution purposes.
A custom URL schema (such as `memory://`) cannot be used for the resolve output
because the in-memory files may use `import.meta.url` in ways that assume a file
URL. `createRequire` from the Node.js `module` builtin is one example of this usage.

Passing Windows CI run: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/actions/runs/6750057482/job/18352859851?pr=26227

Issues.Title: fix(@angular-devkit/build-angular): ensure secondary Angular compilations are unblocked on start errors
Issues.Body:
When using the esbuild-based builders (`application`/`browser-esbuild`), the secondary Angular compilations will wait for the primary compilation to finish prior to bundling. This can potentially occur for polyfills that contain TypeScript files and the server code if enabled. However, if the Angular compilation throws an error during the start of the bundling process, the secondary compilations were never notified and instead would wait indefinitely. To avoid this situation, the compilations will now always be notified at the end of the compilation which will occur regardless. The build error that will be generated in these situations is currently not ideal and more verbose than needed but will provide information pertaining to the root cause.

Closes #26213

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

Calling ng build --delete-output-path=true in a docker container where the `dist` folder is mounted as a volume leads to the following error:

```
EBUSY: resource busy or locked, rmdir '/app/dist'
```

Docker does not allow deleting the root folder of a volume, making it difficult to bind to the dist. (Normally, you wouldn't need to bind the dist folder, but if you're building a custom image to maximize caching, you don't want to bind the volume to the working directory, but just the specific output directories).

You can get around the issue by calling `rm -rf ./dist/* && ng build --delete-output-path=false`. However, this is not tied to the actual configuration, where the output path may be different depending on the configuration.

### Minimal Reproduction

This is slightly contrived, but illustrates the problem (you wouldn't actually want to do this, but it's easier than building an image from scratch):

- Run `docker run -it -v ./dist:/app/dist -v .:/app --rm node:18 /bin/bash` in an angular project
- Run `cd /app` to go to the app
- Run `npx ng build --delete-output-path=true` in the docker container

### Exception or Error

```text
EBUSY: resource busy or locked, rmdir '/app/dist'
```


### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 16.2.8
Node: 18.18.0
Package Manager: pnpm 8.10.2
OS: linux x64

Angular: 16.2.11
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, router

Package                         Version
---------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect       0.1602.8 (cli-only)
@angular-devkit/build-angular   16.2.8
@angular-devkit/core            16.2.8 (cli-only)
@angular-devkit/schematics      16.2.8 (cli-only)
@angular/cdk                    16.2.10

@angular/material               16.2.10
@schematics/angular             16.2.8 (cli-only)
rxjs                            7.8.1
typescript                      5.1.6
zone.js                         0.13.1
```


### Anything else relevant?

It looks like angular calls the `deleteOutputDir` method [here in the browser](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/builders/browser/index.ts#L110) and [here in the server](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/builders/server/index.ts#L220) to delete the output path. The method in question can be found [here](https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/packages/angular_devkit/build_angular/src/utils/delete-output-dir.ts#L15). If we used something like fs-extra's `emptyDirSync` (see [here](https://github.com/jprichardson/node-fs-extra/blob/a277cbbdf630424482b1e7418749ccaac0db98fe/lib/empty/index.js#L20)) instead, we could just empty the output directory rather than deleting it. This would make it a lot more usable and should have theoretically the same impact without running into lock errors or permission errors on the file.

I would put in a PR, but I'm not currently on a machine where that's easy to do!

If this would be considered a breaking change, another thought would be to add another flag. Potentially `--empty-output-path`. That way you could do one or the other.

Issues.Title: bug(MatChipGrid): Chips form controls do not update values until focus is achieved and lost
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

There are several scenarios where this is a breaking bug:
* With a form that has a required chips field and a conditionally disabled element, the element will remain disabled even after the field is valid until it loses focus. This is confusing to users if they don't realize they need to remove focus from the chips field in order for the element to become enabled.
* When a required chips component is the last field in a form, followed by a conditionally disabled submit button and a cancel button, a user may accidentally hit the cancel button if they attempt to tab to the submit button.
* With chips that can be dragged and dropped, the chips field does not necessarily receive focus when chips are moved around. This results in chips being visibly moved, but the form control value does not get updated. Since order generally matters for chips that can be dragged and dropped, a user could get the desired order visually, while a different order gets persisted upon submission.

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-material-chips-bug-f6octd?file=src%2Fmain.ts
Steps to reproduce:
1. Create a required chips field followed by a submit button conditionally enabled by the validation of the preceding field
2. Focus on chips input
3. Select option or type out input
4. Hit **Enter** key on keyboard
5. Hit **Tab** key on keyboard

### Expected Behavior

The submit button should receive focus because it is enabled after hitting **Enter** in the chips field. The chips form control value should be updated immediately when a chip is created.

### Actual Behavior

The submit button does not receive focus.

### Environment

- Angular: 16.2.12
- CDK/Material: 16.2.11
- Browser(s): Tested in Chrome and Firefox, likely reproducible in others
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Tested in Windows, likely reproducible in others

Issues.Body:
These changes remove all the remaining usages of `mixinColor`, `mixinDisabled`, `mixinDisableRipple` and `mixinTabindex` in favor of using input transforms and host bindings. There are still some usages of `mixinErrorState` and `mixinInitialized` that have to be migrated separately.

which is indeed causing options to wrap if too long, but not if they don't contain any white space.

### Expected Behavior

All options with long text, with or without white-spaces, should have a consistent behaviour, either truncate or wrap onto multiple lines.

Two different behaviours as described in the description above
